Long ago, when I started my journey as a developer, Java was the first serious language I committed to.It was trending.It was not â€œeasy.â€It demanded commitment with discipline.It raised the bar of programming standards.Back then, most of the people moving to Java were coming from C or C++ backgrounds. To be productive in C++, you had to be a good programmer, having good command on OOP concepts especially polymorphism. In addition to OOP, you couldnâ€™t fake your way through memory management, pointers, templates and object slicing. Java came in as a more structured, opinionated language, but still demanded solid fundamentals just like C++. In fact, Iâ€™d argue, and IMHO, you rarely see an average programmer doing good in Java. It exposes gaps in your thoughts, and demand a better programming aptitude, not just for syntax, but also for development design especially taking ownership of your code with integration & unit tests.Java developers are often rated as having stronger software engineering and system design skills in hiring benchmarks, especially in enterprise and backend domains.Java doesnâ€™t teach you to just get things done. It teaches you how to think, how to structure, and how to build something that wonâ€™t collapse six months from now.I happily admit and gives credit to Java for my growth, it taught me: - Real-world modeling with OOP & OOAD - Contracts matter with method overloading & overriding (Polymorphism) - Building objects relationships in real world based on class hierarchy using inheritance or object agregation or composition based on loose or tight coupling. - Abstraction & encapsulation to write better code visibility & reusability. - Think yout code by applying design patterns especially "Gang of Four" & design principles like SOLID, KISS, DRY, YAGNI or etc. - The power of the JVM and why type safety matters at scaleAfter working across Pakistan, Japan, US (Remote) and Germany, leading engineering at global companies, migrating systems to the cloud, and building scalable platforms. I still find Javaâ€™s influence in how I think and design. Itâ€™s a legacy of good practises in action.A Stack Overflow Developer Survey still places Java among the most used and loved backend languages, even with all the new frameworks and languages in the ecosystem.For new learners or budding programmers, donâ€™t be discouraged by its rules or verbosity. Those same things will shape you into a better software engineer.Build systems, but also build your legacy.hashtag#java hashtag#programming hashtag#softwaredevelopment hashtag#softwareengineering hashtag#developermindset hashtag#techleadership hashtag#cleancode hashtag#engineeringgrowth hashtag#growthmindset hashtag#objectorienteddesign hashtag#objectorientedprogramming hashtag#softwarecraftsmanship hashtag#lifelonglearner

A quick thought on remote work and security...Lately, Iâ€™ve been seeing a lot of companies push return-to-office policies. The reason? "Security concerns."But hereâ€™s my take - remote work isnâ€™t insecure by default. What makes it insecure is the absence of structure.When teams are logging in from everywhere without a VPN, using personal devices, or sharing access looselyâ€”itâ€™s not the remote part thatâ€™s the problem. Itâ€™s the setup. The companies Iâ€™ve seen succeed with remote work donâ€™t treat it like a perk. They treat it like a system.A system with:â€“ Clear device policies â€“ Enforced MFA â€“ Role-based access â€“ Regular training (yes, even short, informal ones help)Set it up right, and it works. Efficiency stays high, risks stay low, and people get to do great work without sitting in traffic five days a week. Itâ€™s not about where we workâ€”itâ€™s about how we manage it.Curious if anyone else is seeing this shift. Are you going back to the officeâ€”or doubling down on getting remote right?hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#CyberSecurity hashtag#Leadership hashtag#WorkplaceSecurity hashtag#InfoSec hashtag#WorkTrends

Day 58/100 â€“ Method Overriding & Runtime Polymorphism in JavaToday I explored Method Overriding â€” a key feature of runtime polymorphism in Java!In this example:A parent1 class has a method show()A child0 class overrides the same methodAt runtime, the childâ€™s method is executed, even though the reference is of the parent type!Code Output:javaCopy codeparent1 p = new child0();p.show();  // Output: "child class method"Why this matters:Enables dynamic method dispatchPromotes loose couplingMakes Java truly object-orientedLesson of the Day:Itâ€™s not about the reference, itâ€™s about the object behind it!hashtag#100DaysOfCode hashtag#Java hashtag#OOP hashtag#Polymorphism hashtag#MethodOverriding hashtag#RuntimeMagic hashtag#CodeBetter hashtag#Jainuniversity Dr Sagar Gulati Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.A â˜•ï¸ğŸ’¡ğŸ”ğŸ§ âœ¨

Day 18 : Understanding the difference between == and .equals() in Java is crucial for comparing objects correctly. Here's a fun and interactive way to grasp these concepts.ğŸ§  Understanding == vs .equals() in JavağŸ” The == OperatorWhat it does: Checks if two references point to the exact same object in memory.Use case: Best for comparing primitive data types (like int, char) or checking if two object references are identical.Medium+2Medium+2Scaler+2ğŸ§ª The .equals() MethodWhat it does: Compares the actual content or state of two objects.Use case: Ideal for comparing the contents of objects, such as strings, to see if they are logically "equal."ğŸ–¼ï¸ Visual RepresentationImagine two identical books:Scenario 1: Both friends are reading the same physical book. This is like using ==; both references point to the same object.Scenario 2: Each friend has their own copy of the book with the same  content. This is like using .equals(); different objects, but               identical content.ğŸ® Interactive Coding ChallengeLet's play a game with Java strings!javaCopyEditpublic class StringComparison { public static void main(String[] args) { String magicWord1 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord2 = "Abracadabra"; String magicWord3 = new String("Abracadabra"); System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord2); // What will this print? System.out.println(magicWord1 == magicWord3); // And this? System.out.println(magicWord1.equals(magicWord3)); // How about this? }}ğŸ“Œ Follow along and challenge yourself daily!ğŸ’¡ I'll be sharing one Java trick daily! Follow along and let's grow together. ğŸš€ğŸ”” Follow me to get these updates!ğŸ’¬ Which Java trick interests you most? Share below! ğŸ‘‡hashtag#Java hashtag#Coding hashtag#Programming hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment hashtag#SpringBoot hashtag#DailyJavaTrick hashtag#20DaysOfCode

Long ago, when I started my journey as a developer, Java was the first serious language I committed to.It was trending.It was not â€œeasy.â€It demanded commitment with discipline.It raised the bar of programming standards.Back then, most of the people moving to Java were coming from C or C++ backgrounds. To be productive in C++, you had to be a good programmer, having good command on OOP concepts especially polymorphism. In addition to OOP, you couldnâ€™t fake your way through memory management, pointers, templates and object slicing. Java came in as a more structured, opinionated language, but still demanded solid fundamentals just like C++. In fact, Iâ€™d argue, and IMHO, you rarely see an average programmer doing good in Java. It exposes gaps in your thoughts, and demand a better programming aptitude, not just for syntax, but also for development design especially taking ownership of your code with integration & unit tests.Java developers are often rated as having stronger software engineering and system design skills in hiring benchmarks, especially in enterprise and backend domains.Java doesnâ€™t teach you to just get things done. It teaches you how to think, how to structure, and how to build something that wonâ€™t collapse six months from now.I happily admit and gives credit to Java for my growth, it taught me: - Real-world modeling with OOP & OOAD - Contracts matter with method overloading & overriding (Polymorphism) - Building objects relationships in real world based on class hierarchy using inheritance or object agregation or composition based on loose or tight coupling. - Abstraction & encapsulation to write better code visibility & reusability. - Think yout code by applying design patterns especially "Gang of Four" & design principles like SOLID, KISS, DRY, YAGNI or etc. - The power of the JVM and why type safety matters at scaleAfter working across Pakistan, Japan, US (Remote) and Germany, leading engineering at global companies, migrating systems to the cloud, and building scalable platforms. I still find Javaâ€™s influence in how I think and design. Itâ€™s a legacy of good practises in action.A Stack Overflow Developer Survey still places Java among the most used and loved backend languages, even with all the new frameworks and languages in the ecosystem.For new learners or budding programmers, donâ€™t be discouraged by its rules or verbosity. Those same things will shape you into a better software engineer.Build systems, but also build your legacy.hashtag#java hashtag#programming hashtag#softwaredevelopment hashtag#softwareengineering hashtag#developermindset hashtag#techleadership hashtag#cleancode hashtag#engineeringgrowth hashtag#growthmindset hashtag#objectorienteddesign hashtag#objectorientedprogramming hashtag#softwarecraftsmanship hashtag#lifelonglearner

A quick thought on remote work and security...Lately, Iâ€™ve been seeing a lot of companies push return-to-office policies. The reason? "Security concerns."But hereâ€™s my take - remote work isnâ€™t insecure by default. What makes it insecure is the absence of structure.When teams are logging in from everywhere without a VPN, using personal devices, or sharing access looselyâ€”itâ€™s not the remote part thatâ€™s the problem. Itâ€™s the setup. The companies Iâ€™ve seen succeed with remote work donâ€™t treat it like a perk. They treat it like a system.A system with:â€“ Clear device policies â€“ Enforced MFA â€“ Role-based access â€“ Regular training (yes, even short, informal ones help)Set it up right, and it works. Efficiency stays high, risks stay low, and people get to do great work without sitting in traffic five days a week. Itâ€™s not about where we workâ€”itâ€™s about how we manage it.Curious if anyone else is seeing this shift. Are you going back to the officeâ€”or doubling down on getting remote right?hashtag#RemoteWork hashtag#CyberSecurity hashtag#Leadership hashtag#WorkplaceSecurity hashtag#InfoSec hashtag#WorkTrends

Day 58/100 â€“ Method Overriding & Runtime Polymorphism in JavaToday I explored Method Overriding â€” a key feature of runtime polymorphism in Java!In this example:A parent1 class has a method show()A child0 class overrides the same methodAt runtime, the childâ€™s method is executed, even though the reference is of the parent type!Code Output:javaCopy codeparent1 p = new child0();p.show();  // Output: "child class method"Why this matters:Enables dynamic method dispatchPromotes loose couplingMakes Java truly object-orientedLesson of the Day:Itâ€™s not about the reference, itâ€™s about the object behind it!hashtag#100DaysOfCode hashtag#Java hashtag#OOP hashtag#Polymorphism hashtag#MethodOverriding hashtag#RuntimeMagic hashtag#CodeBetter hashtag#Jainuniversity Dr Sagar Gulati Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.A â˜•ï¸ğŸ’¡ğŸ”ğŸ§ âœ¨
